body: wonders if she'd ever be brave enoughand turn it into something cartoon-funny.Would their world not remain comfortablyIV. The Paths to CathayThe edge of that other square cut from the rightThe form sought for centuries bySome stubborn sprouts up through the stubble hay,Sought to contrive, intending to expressNot daring to opposeThrough the back of the picture at the patch of whiteStunned in their voiceless way to be aliveI do not betray you, I still go forward,He is harsh, dismal, ice—that is, exiled;The weight of being born into exile is lifted.And so I gaze avidlyHigh on this surface, guarding the edge of Pèrewatching calisthenics from the grandstands.Seen. What you know is only manifestWind, sleet. The branches sway,
